## CES-D vs ASSIST

Psychologists and social scientists are often tasked with comparing and harmonising questionnaires, such as the Center for Epidemiological Studies-Depression (CES-D) and the Alcohol, Smoking, and Substance Involvement Screening Test - Substance Use (ASSIST). Having a reliable tool to assist in this process can greatly reduce time and effort. **Harmony**, a software developed for this purpose, uses natural language processing and generative AI models to harmonise questionnaire items, making the CES-D vs ASSIST comparison process both simple and efficient. The CES-D vs ASSIST comparison is just one example of how Harmony can be utilized. Assessing the degree of similarity between items in CES-D, a measure of depressive symptoms, and ASSIST, a substance use screening tool, allows researchers to draw meaningful relationships between different facets of mental health. With Harmony, users can easily select these instruments from the database or upload their own, and obtain a percentage similarity report, even where the items are in different languages. In the growing field of mental health research, tools like Harmony are invaluable. By facilitating the CES-D vs ASSIST comparison, Harmony makes it possible to gain insights across studies and across languages. With this kind of powerful tool, research can progress more efficiently, providing valuable findings for the benefit of all. The next time youâ€™re faced with the task of comparing CES-D vs ASSIST or any other assessment instruments, consider using Harmony, your reliable assistant for questionnaire harmonisation.
